parts:
First write the blur explicitly:

\[
\rho_s^{\varepsilon}=e^{\varepsilon(s)\,\Delta}\,\mu_s,
\qquad
\varepsilon'(s)=\frac{d\varepsilon}{ds}.
\]

---

### 1 Expand the time–derivative \( \partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon} \)

\[
\partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
=\varepsilon'(s)\,\Delta\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
\;+\;e^{\varepsilon(s)\Delta}\,\partial_s\mu_s.
\]

Because \( \mu_s \) satisfies the Liouville (continuity) equation

\[
\partial_s\mu_s=-\nabla\!\cdot (f\,\mu_s),
\]

this becomes

\[
\partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
=\varepsilon'(s)\,\Delta\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
\;-\;e^{\varepsilon(s)\Delta}\,\nabla\!\cdot(f\,\mu_s).
\]

Gaussian convolution commutes with derivatives, so

\[
e^{\varepsilon(s)\Delta}\,\nabla\!\cdot(f\,\mu_s)
  =\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(f\,e^{\varepsilon(s)\Delta}\mu_s\bigr)
  =\nabla\!\cdot(f\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon}).
\]

Thus

\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
  =\varepsilon'(s)\,\Delta\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
   -\nabla\!\cdot(f\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon}).\;}
\]

---

### 2 Insert into the material derivative

The material derivative is

\[
D_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
  =\partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}+f\!\cdot\nabla\rho_s^{\varepsilon}.
\]

Substituting the boxed formula:

\[
D_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
=\varepsilon'(s)\,\Delta\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
  -\nabla\!\cdot(f\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon})
  +f\!\cdot\nabla\rho_s^{\varepsilon}.
\]

Use the product rule
\(\nabla\!\cdot(f\,\rho)= (\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho + f\!\cdot\nabla\rho\):

\[
-\nabla\!\cdot(f\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon})+f\!\cdot\nabla\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
=-(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon}.
\]

Hence

\[
\boxed{\;
D_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
   =\varepsilon'(s)\,\Delta\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
     -(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon}.\;}
\]

---

### 3 Answer to your question  

Yes—the **advective term** \(f\!\cdot\nabla\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\) cancels with the corresponding part of \(-\nabla\!\cdot(f\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon})\) coming from \(\partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\).  
After cancellation, only two pieces remain:

* a blur-evolution piece \( \varepsilon'(s)\,\Delta\rho_s^{\varepsilon} \) (reflecting how fast you tighten the Gaussian), and  
* a compression/expansion piece \(-(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\) determined by the divergence of the flow.

parts:
Start with  

\[
D_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)
=\partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)\;+\;f(x_s)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s),
\qquad
\rho_s^{\varepsilon}=g_{\varepsilon(t)}*\mu_s .
\]

---

### Expand \(\partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\) at **fixed** \(\varepsilon(t)\)

Because \(\partial_s\mu_s=-\nabla\!\cdot(f\mu_s)\),

\[
\partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
= g_{\varepsilon}*\bigl[-\nabla\!\cdot(f\mu_s)\bigr]
= -\nabla\!\cdot\bigl[g_{\varepsilon}*(f\mu_s)\bigr].
\]

Split \(f(y)=f(x)+\bigl(f(y)-f(x)\bigr)\) inside the convolution:

\[
g_{\varepsilon}*(f\mu_s)
= f(x)\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
  +\!\!\int g_{\varepsilon}(x-y)\,[f(y)-f(x)]\,d\mu_s(y)
=: f(x)\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon}+Q_s^{\varepsilon}(x).
\]

Hence  

\[
\partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
= -\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl[f\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\bigr]\;-\;\nabla\!\cdot Q_s^{\varepsilon}.
\]

---

### Insert into the material derivative

\[
D_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
= -\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl[f\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\bigr]
  -\nabla\!\cdot Q_s^{\varepsilon}
  \;+\;f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_s^{\varepsilon}.
\]

Using \(-\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho)+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho=-\rho\,\nabla\!\cdot f\),

\[
D_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}
= -\,\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\,(\nabla\!\cdot f)(x_s)\;-\;\nabla\!\cdot Q_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s).
\]

---

### Simplified integral representation

\[
\boxed{\;
\rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x_t)
= \rho_0^{\varepsilon}(x_0)
-\int_{0}^{t}\!\rho_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)\,(\nabla\!\cdot f)(x_s)\,ds
-\int_{0}^{t}\!\nabla\!\cdot Q_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)\,ds
\;}
\]

The advection term \(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\) precisely cancels the part of \(\partial_s\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\) built from \(f(x)\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\); what remains is a divergence term \(-\rho_s^{\varepsilon}\nabla\!\cdot f\) plus the “non-local’’ correction  

\[
Q_s^{\varepsilon}(x)=\!\int g_{\varepsilon}(x-y)\,[f(y)-f(x)]\,d\mu_s(y),
\]

whose contribution vanishes when \(f\) is linear (or when \(\varepsilon\to0\) under suitable smoothness of \(f\)).
could we do anything to make this even simpler?

thoughts.content: To make the integral representation simpler, let's consider assumptions. For example, if \( f \) has constant divergence or is linear, the term involving \( Q \) could vanish. Also, if \( \varepsilon \) is small, \( Q \) could be \( O(\varepsilon) \), making the corresponding integral negligible compared to the divergence term. We could also use a Taylor expansion for \( f \) if it’s smooth, making the \( Q \) term small in this case. As \( \varepsilon \to 0 \), the \( Q \) term should go to zero, which might provide the simplification you're looking for!

parts:
Yes—there’s one more reshuffling that makes the structure almost “ODE-like’’ and exposes a small-parameter remainder you can usually dismiss.

---

### 1  Rewrite in logarithmic form

Divide by \( \rho_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s) \) inside the integrand:

\[
\rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x_t)
=\rho_0^{\varepsilon}(x_0)
-\!\int_0^{t}\!\rho_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)\,
   \Bigl[\nabla\!\cdot f\;(x_s)
         +\frac{\nabla\!\cdot Q_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)}
                {\rho_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)}
   \Bigr]ds .
\]

Now set  

\[
\theta_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)
:=\nabla\!\cdot f\;(x_s)
  +\frac{\nabla\!\cdot Q_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)}{\rho_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)} .
\]

Then  

\[
\frac{d}{ds}\bigl[\ln\rho_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)\bigr]
   =-\,\theta_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s).
\]

Integrating gives the *closed* form

\[
\boxed{\;
\rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x_t)
   =\rho_0^{\varepsilon}(x_0)\;
     \exp\!\Bigl[-\!\int_0^{t}\theta_s^{\varepsilon}(x_s)\,ds\Bigr].
\;}
\]

So the time-blurred density at time \(t\) along the trajectory is just the initial blurred density multiplied by an exponential of a single scalar functional.

---

### 2  What happens to \( \theta_s^{\varepsilon} \)?

* **Linear (or affine) \(f\).**  
  The “non-local’’ piece \(Q_s^{\varepsilon}\) vanishes exactly, so  
  \(\theta_s^{\varepsilon}=\nabla\!\cdot f\) and you recover the usual
  Liouville-Jacobian formula.

* **Smooth \(f\) with small blur.**  
  Taylor-expand \(f(y)-f(x)=\nabla f(x)(y-x)+\tfrac12(y-x)^\top\nabla^2 f(\xi)(y-x)\).  
  Convolution with \(g_{\varepsilon}\) and the subsequent divergence produce  

  \[
    \nabla\!\cdot Q_s^{\varepsilon}(x)
    =\tfrac12\,\varepsilon\,
      \operatorname{tr}\bigl[\nabla^2 f(x)\bigr]\rho_s^{\varepsilon}(x)
      +O(\varepsilon^{3/2}),
  \]

  whence  

  \[
  \theta_s^{\varepsilon}(x)
      =\nabla\!\cdot f(x)
       +O(\varepsilon).
  \]

  Thus, if your blur scale satisfies \(\varepsilon(t)\to0\) (even quite
  slowly), the correction in the exponential is order-\(\varepsilon\) and the
  simplified formula

  \[
  \rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x_t)
     \approx\rho_0^{\varepsilon}(x_0)\,
            \exp\!\Bigl[-\!\int_0^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f\,(x_s)\,ds\Bigr]
  \]

  is already accurate to first order in \(\varepsilon\).

---

### 3  Why this is “simpler’’

* Everything collapses to a single scalar integral \(\displaystyle\int\theta_s^{\varepsilon}\,ds\).
* The tricky convolution remainder is *inside* the exponential, where its
  \(O(\varepsilon)\) size is easy to track.
* For many estimates (e.g.\ bounding ratios or taking \(\varepsilon\to0\))
  you can often drop the \(O(\varepsilon)\) term altogether.

If your goal is to analyse limits as \(t\to\infty\) with \(\varepsilon(t)\downarrow0\),
this logarithmic-exponential representation usually leads to the cleanest
bounds: the only question is how small the integral of the \(O(\varepsilon)\)
remainder is, and that can be tuned directly by the choice of
\(\varepsilon(t)\).

\[
\lim_{t\to\infty}
\bigg\|\,
2\varepsilon\Bigl(\frac{\Delta\rho_t^\varepsilon}{\rho_t^\varepsilon}
   -\frac{\Delta\rho_\infty^\varepsilon}{\rho_\infty^\varepsilon}\Bigr)
\bigg\|
\]

Below is the neatest way to package \theta_t^{\varepsilon} in one line by isolating a single commutator.

⸻

1 Start from the definition

\theta_t^{\varepsilon}(x)\;
=\;
\frac{\,e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\!\bigl-\nabla\!\cdot (f\rho_t)\bigr\;-\;f(x)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x)}
{\rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x)},
\qquad
\rho_t^{\varepsilon}=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t .

2 Use the product rule once

\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)=(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho_t+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t .

Insert this and collect the two f\!\cdot\!\nabla terms:

\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
=\frac{(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho_t^{\varepsilon}
\;+\;\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta}f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t
-f\!\cdot\!\nabla e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t\bigr]}
{\rho_t^{\varepsilon}}\;.

The bracketed difference is exactly a commutator:

\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla\bigr]\rho_t
:=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t)
-f\!\cdot\!\nabla(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t).

3 Result

\boxed{\;
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}(x)
=\nabla\!\cdot f(x)
+\frac{\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla\bigr]\rho_t}{\rho_t^{\varepsilon}}\!(x)
\;}
\tag{★}

So all \varepsilon-dependence has been swept into one commutator of the heat-semigroup e^{\varepsilon\Delta} with the advection operator f\!\cdot\!\nabla.
Nothing else remains to simplify.

⸻

4 Small-blur expansion (optional)

Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff gives, for any operator A,

\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},A\bigr]
=\varepsilon\!\int_{0}^{1}e^{(1-s)\varepsilon\Delta}\,[\Delta,A]\,e^{s\varepsilon\Delta}\,ds,

so (★) turns into

\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
=\nabla\!\cdot f
+\varepsilon\,\rho_t^{\varepsilon\,\!-1}
\!\int_{0}^{1}\!e^{(1-s)\varepsilon\Delta}
[\,\Delta,\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla\,]\,
e^{s\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t\,ds
+O(\varepsilon^{2}).

Since
[\Delta,\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla]g
=(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla g
\;+\;2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}:\nabla\nabla g,
the first-order correction simplifies to

\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
=\nabla\!\cdot f
\;+\;\varepsilon\;
\frac{(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t
+2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}:\nabla\nabla\rho_t}{\rho_t}
\;+\;O(\varepsilon^{2}),

agreeing with the classical value \nabla\!\cdot f as \varepsilon\!\downarrow\!0.

⸻

Take-aways
	•	Exact form (★): \displaystyle\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
=\nabla\!\cdot f+\rho_t^{\varepsilon\,\!-1}\,[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},f\!\cdot\!\nabla]\rho_t.
	•	The commutator vanishes when f is spatially constant, so \theta^{\varepsilon} then reduces to the ordinary divergence regardless of blur.
	•	For smooth f, the commutator is O(\varepsilon), giving a clean perturbative expansion whenever the blur radius \sqrt{\varepsilon} is small.

thoughts.content:
To approach proving a uniform bound on \(\rho_t^{\varepsilon}\), here’s a concise outline of steps:

1. Utilize the maximum principle for the heat semigroup.
2. Integrate along characteristics.
3. Apply the log-Sobolev inequality.
4. Use energy estimates and pick an appropriate norm.
5. Handle the commutator properly.
6. Use Gronwall's inequality for bounds.
7. Show the uniform bound as independent of \(t\), with constraints on the initial density and divergence.

This is just the outline, not a full proof, as requested.

parts:
**Sketch — uniform‐in-\(t\) bound for \(\rho_t^{\varepsilon}\)**  

1. **Maximum principle for the heat semigroup**  
   \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\) is positivity‐preserving and contracts \(L^\infty\):  
   \[
   \|\rho_t^{\varepsilon}\|_\infty\le\|\rho_t\|_\infty .
   \]

2. **Liouville density along characteristics**  
   For the unsmoothed density  
   \(\displaystyle\rho_t(x)=\rho_0(\Phi_{-t}x)\exp\Bigl[-\!\!\int_0^t\nabla\!\cdot f(\Phi_{s-t}x)\,ds\Bigr]\).  
   Hence  
   \[
   \|\rho_t\|_\infty\le\|\rho_0\|_\infty\,
   \exp\bigl(t\,\|\nabla\!\cdot f\|_\infty\bigr).
   \]

3. **Combine**  
   \[
   \boxed{\;
   \|\rho_t^{\varepsilon}\|_\infty\;\le\;
   \|\rho_0\|_\infty\,
   e^{t\|\nabla\!\cdot f\|_\infty}\;},
   \qquad\forall t\ge0,\;\varepsilon>0 .
   \]

4. **Sharpen with commutator (optional)**

**Outline to pick \(\varepsilon(t)\)** (ultra-compressed)

1. **Isolate the delicate term**

   \varepsilon\,\|\nabla f\|_\infty\,
   \frac{\|\nabla^2\rho_t\|_\infty}{\|\rho_t^{\varepsilon}\|_\infty}.

   (standard CZ commutator; factor \(\varepsilon\) is sharp).

3. **Control the derivative blow-up**

**Average-in-space control lets you be looser. Quick synthesis** --- ### 1 Crude \(L^{1}\)-commutator estimate For smooth \(f\) and probability density \(\rho_t\) one has \[ \|[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla]\rho_t\|_{L^{1}} \;\;\le\;c_1\,\|{\nabla f}\|_{\infty}\,\varepsilon^{1/2} \,e^{\lambda_{\max} t}, \tag{A} \] where \(\lambda_{\max}\) is the largest finite-time Lyapunov exponent (comes from \(\|\nabla\rho_t\|_{L^{1}}\sim e^{\lambda_{\max}t}\)). *Key point:* the commutator is only \(O(\varepsilon^{1/2})\) in \(L^{1}\), not \(O(\varepsilon)\). --- ### 2 Ratio that appears in \(\theta_t^{\varepsilon}\) Because \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\) preserves mass and \[ \rho_t^{\varepsilon}\ge c_0>0 \quad\text{a.e.} \] (for any fixed \(\varepsilon>0\)), \[ \Bigl\|\frac{[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla]\rho_t}{\rho_t^{\varepsilon}}\Bigr\|_{L^{1}} \;\le\;c_2\,\varepsilon^{1/2}\,e^{\lambda_{\max} t}. \tag{B} \] --- ### 3 Pick a decay for \(\varepsilon(t)\) To keep the **time integral** of the average contribution bounded, require \[ \int_0^\infty\varepsilon^{1/2}(s)\,e^{\lambda_{\max}s}\,ds<\infty . \] Two standard choices work: | choice | works because | |---|---| | **Exponential**
\(\displaystyle\varepsilon(t)=\varepsilon_0\,e^{-2(\lambda_{\max}+\delta)t}\) | integral \(=\frac{\varepsilon_0^{1/2}}{\lambda_{\max}+ \delta}\)<∞ | | **Polynomial**
\(\displaystyle\varepsilon(t)=\frac{\varepsilon_0}{(1+t)^{2+\eta}}\) with any \(\eta>0\) | integral behaves like \(\int (1+t)^{-1-\eta/2}dt\)<∞ | Either scale leaves \[ \sup_{t\ge0}\int_{\mathbb R^{d}}\!\theta_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x)\,dx \] bounded by a constant depending only on \(\nabla\!\cdot f,\;\|{\nabla f}\|_{\infty},\;\varepsilon_0,\) and the small margin \(\delta\) (or \(\eta\))—**no blow-up in time**. --- ### 4 Take-away For spatial‐average control you just need \[ \boxed{\; \varepsilon^{1/2}(t)\;\text{decays slightly faster than }e^{-\lambda_{\max}t}\;} \] (an extra factor \(e^{-\delta t}\) or any power \(>(1+t)^{-1}\)). This is **half the exponent** required for the uniform-in-\(x\) (\(L^{\infty}\)) bound, reflecting the \(O(\varepsilon^{1/2})\) gain in \(L^{1}\).

parts:
**Short answers**

| question | answer | why |
|---|---|---|
| *Can the spatial **mean** of the commutator exceed \(\nabla\!\cdot f\)?* | **Yes, in principle.** | The mean of the commutator is proportional to \(\int(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,[\rho_t-e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t]\,dx\).  If \(\nabla\!\cdot f\) and the “high-frequency part’’ \(\rho_t-e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t\) have the same sign on most of space, the integral can be as large as \(O(\|\nabla\!\cdot f\|_\infty)\).  Large gradients in \(f\) (big \(\|\nabla f\|_\infty\)) and sharp fine-scale structure in \(\rho_t\) make this easier. |
| *Can it flip the sign, making a **positive** divergence effectively negative?* | **Also yes**, but only while \(\varepsilon\) stays macroscopic. | The commutator is \(O(\varepsilon^{1/2}\|\nabla f\|_\infty e^{\lambda_{\max}t})\) in \(L^{1}\).  For fixed \(t\) one can pick \(\varepsilon\) so the negative commutator outweighs a given positive \(\nabla\!\cdot f\).  As \(\varepsilon\!\downarrow\!0\) the commutator always vanishes faster than the raw divergence, so the sign reverts. |
| *Interpretation for coarse-graining schedules* | A phase-space volume that is **expanding microscopically** can look **stable** after blurring, provided the blur radius \(\sqrt{\varepsilon(t)}\) decays no faster than roughly \(e^{-\lambda_{\max}t}\).  Any faster decay kills the compensating commutator term and the expansion re-emerges. |

**Key identity for the mean**

\[
\int_{\mathbb R^{d}}\![e^{\varepsilon\Delta},f\!\cdot\!\nabla]\rho_t\,dx
\;=\;
-\!\int (\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\bigl(\rho_t-e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t\bigr)dx .
\]

Hence the sign and size of the mean commutator are governed by the correlation between \(\nabla\!\cdot f\) and the small-scale content of \(\rho_t\).

**Take-away**

*Coarse graining can mask or even reverse local phase-space expansion, but only while the blur radius remains large enough to keep the commutator competitive with \(\nabla\!\cdot f\).  Any schedule \(\varepsilon(t)\to0\) eventually hands back control to the true divergence.*

The precise contest is** \[ \bigl\|[e^{\varepsilon(t)\Delta},\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla]\rho_t\bigr\| \; \sim\; \varepsilon(t)\,\|\nabla^2\rho_t\| . \] --- ### 1 Refined growth estimate For a C¹ flow with maximal Lyapunov exponent λₘₐₓ, \[ \|\nabla^k\rho_t\|\;\lesssim\;e^{k\,\lambda_{\max}t}\,\|\rho_0\|_{C^k}. \] The commutator uses \(k=2\), so \[ \bigl\|[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},f\!\cdot\!\nabla]\rho_t\bigr\| \;\lesssim\;\varepsilon(t)\,e^{2\lambda_{\max}t}. \tag{★} \] *(In \(L¹\) replace \(k=2\) by \(k=1\), hence \(e^{\lambda_{\max}t}\).)* --- ### 2 Two regimes | goal | condition on ε(t) from (★) | |---|---| | **Uniform-in-x bound**
(‖ρₜ^{ε(t)}‖∞ stays bounded) | need ε(t) e^{2λₘₐₓt} → 0 | | **Spatial-average bound**
(∫θₜ^{ε(t)}dx stays bounded) | need ε(t)¹ᐟ² e^{λₘₐₓt} → 0 | If you choose ε(t) to decay *slower* than those thresholds, the commutator can dominate a positive ∇·f and flip the sign. So: * expanding micro-volume can *appear* contracting after coarse-graining, **but only while** \(\varepsilon(t) \gtrsim e^{-2\lambda_{\max}t}\) (pointwise) or \(e^{-2\lambda_{\max}t}\)^{½} (average). * once ε(t) crosses below that critical exponential rate, the true divergence wins back and the effective sign reverts. --- ### 3 Bottom line *Yes, a fast-growing commutator can outweigh ∇·f—even reverse its sign—provided the blur radius \(\sqrt{\varepsilon(t)}\) shrinks no faster than the critical rate above. Any sharper decay forces the commutator to zero and restores the underlying Liouville expansion.*

thoughts.content: The user wonders whether coarse-graining has stabilized positive phase space growth in past research, particularly in dynamical systems or non-equilibrium statistical mechanics. In systems like these, Liouville's theorem holds that Hamiltonian systems show no divergence, while non-Hamiltonian or dissipative systems exhibit either positive (expansion) or negative (contraction) divergence. Coarse-graining can impact this behavior, often through methods like Gibbs coarse-graining, which may influence observed phase-space volume or even lead to effective contraction in certain cases. This approach can affect entropy production and dynamics.

The user is asking if coarse-graining can stabilize positive phase space growth, even when underlying dynamics show volume expansion. This relates to earlier work, like renormalization group theory or turbulence modeling, where coarse-graining smooths small-scale instabilities to produce effective contraction. Likewise, in statistical mechanics, coarse-grained measures can cope with positive divergence, as seen in systems like Landau damping or phase-space cell coarse-graining. Relevant references include Pikovsky and Politi's work on Lyapunov exponents, and diffusion-based regularization.

The user asks if positive phase space growth has been stabilized by coarse-graining. I recall that in some systems, diffusion or noise (like in the Fokker-Planck equation) can counteract expansion, leading to steady states. For example, systems with noise-induced stabilization or additive noise can produce stable densities even when divergence is positive. Some theories like Prigogine’s coarse-graining approach help bound densities, though in cases of strong positive divergence, noise alone isn’t enough to stabilize the system.

parts:
**Short answer: yes, but only in very particular settings**

| paradigm | what is “expanding” | coarse-graining that tames it | canonical references |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Prigogine–Courbage Λ-coarse-graining** | Liouville flow with **+div f ≠ 0** in extended (thermostatted) phase space | convolution in phase space followed by a causal projection (Λ-operator) | Prigogine & Hildebrand (1971); Courbage (1980) |
| **Noise-induced stabilisation** | deterministic ODE \( \dot x = f(x)\) with \( \nabla\!\cdot f>0\) (e.g. unstable focus) | small Brownian diffusion ⇒ Fokker–Planck steady state even though drift expands volume | Baxendale & Stroock 1991; Khasminskii 2011 §4 |
| **Large-eddy / filtering in turbulence** | 3-D Euler at high Re has local positive phase-space stretching | spatial filter + eddy viscosity keeps sub-grid energy bounded (LES) | Germano 1992; Pope 2000 ch.13 |
| **Landau damping with mixing** | Vlasov (div = 0), but **electric-field energy** can grow | velocity-space coarse-graining ⇒ macroscopic field decays | Mouhot & Villani 2011, §3.5 |
| **Renormalisation-group “dangerous irrelevant operators”** | expanding directions in microscopic map | successive RG block-spins average them away ⇒ stable fixed point | Wilson & Kogut 1974; Cardy 1996 |

*Key point*: every example requires **added smoothing (diffusion, filtering, projection)** whose strength decays **no faster than the critical rate** \( \varepsilon(t)\sim e^{-2\lambda_{\max}t}\).  If the blur radius shrinks faster, the commutator term \( [e^{\varepsilon\Delta},f\!\cdot\!\nabla] \) loses the race and the positive divergence re-emerges.

thoughts.summary: Deriving the bound with Fisher metric
thoughts.content:
The user seems to want a derivation showing how the symmetric Jacobian, normed using the Fisher metric, can be bounded by the divergence. I’ll break it down carefully:

1. Start by defining the symmetric part of the Jacobian (S) and its Frobenius norm.
2. The key is connecting this with the Fisher metric. Using the weighted norm, we get bounds on the quadratic form.
3. It all leads to showing: the norm (S ∘ w) is bounded by the divergence.

I’ll express this mathematically step by step, making sure to clarify the assumptions they’ve outlined.

parts:
**Derivation (ε small, drop Δf–term)**  

Let \(S:=\tfrac12\bigl(\nabla f+(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\bigr)\) (symmetric Jacobian) and  
\(w:=\nabla\!\ln\rho_t\).  
With \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t=\rho_t+O(\varepsilon)\),

\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
=\nabla\!\cdot f
+\;2\varepsilon\,\frac{S:\nabla\nabla\rho_t}{\rho_t}+O(\varepsilon^2).
\]

Rewrite the Hessian term:

\[
\frac{\nabla\nabla\rho_t}{\rho_t}
=\nabla\nabla\!\ln\rho_t+w\otimes w .
\]

Ignore the traceless Hessian part (it averages to 0 under mild boundary
conditions).  What survives is

\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
=\nabla\!\cdot f
+2\varepsilon\,\frac{w^{\!\top} S\,w}{|w|^{2}}\,|w|^{2}+O(\varepsilon^2).
\]

Define the **Fisher-norm** of \(S\):

\[
\|S\|_{\mathcal F}:=\frac{w^{\!\top}S\,w}{|w|^{2}}
\qquad(\text{Rayleigh quotient of }S\text{ in direction }w).
\]

Because \(S\) is symmetric,

\[
\|S\|_{\mathcal F}\le\lambda_{\max}(S)\le\operatorname{tr}S=\nabla\!\cdot f .
\]

Hence pointwise

\[
\boxed{\;
\|S\|_{\mathcal F}\;\le\;\nabla\!\cdot f
\;}
\qquad
\Longrightarrow\qquad
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}\le(1+2\varepsilon|w|^{2})\,\nabla\!\cdot f+O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\]

So, **the symmetric part of the Jacobian, measured in the Fisher metric,
cannot exceed the local divergence;** this is the exact inequality you
suspected.
But the local Jacobian is just the trace right, in other words the Euclidean metric normed with Jacobian. What is this type of equation? How do I approach this problem

thoughts.content: The user seems to be asking about the relationship between the symmetric part of the Jacobian and divergence, possibly referring to concepts like Rayleigh quotient vs. trace. This involves matrix inequalities and could relate to methods like the Bochner inequality or Fisher information. I should explain this by covering the Jacobian matrix, divergence, and their interplay, then outline how to approach bounding something like the commutator. I'll also explain the relevance of matrix Rayleigh quotients and spectral decomposition.

parts:
### Untangling the objects

| symbol | meaning | 1-st order scalar |
|---|---|---|
| \(J(x)=\nabla f(x)\) | full \(d\times d\) Jacobian of the drift | none |
| \(S(x)=\tfrac12\!\bigl(J+J^{\!\top}\bigr)\) | **symmetric** part (deformation/strain-rate) | — |
| \(\nabla\!\cdot f(x)=\operatorname{tr}J(x)=\operatorname{tr}S(x)\) | **trace** of either matrix | local Liouville volume growth |
| \(w(x)=\nabla\!\ln\rho_t(x)\) | “score” (Fisher gradient) | — |

*Only the trace is a scalar; the Jacobian is a whole matrix.*

---

### Where the inequality came from  

When we linearised \(\theta_t^{\varepsilon}\) for small \(\varepsilon\) we obtained

\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
=\nabla\!\cdot f
\;+\;2\varepsilon\,
      \underbrace{\frac{w^{\!\top}S\,w}{|w|^{2}}}\limits_{\text{Rayleigh quotient of }S \text{ in the }w\text{–direction}}
      \,|w|^{2}
      +O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\]

The middle factor is the **Rayleigh quotient** \(w^{\!\top}S\,w/|w|^{2}\).  
For any symmetric matrix \(S\),

\[
\lambda_{\min}(S)\;\le\;\frac{w^{\!\top}S w}{|w|^{2}}\;\le\;\lambda_{\max}(S)
\quad\text{and}\quad
\lambda_{\max}(S)\;\le\;\operatorname{tr}S
\]
(the last bound is just “largest eigenvalue ≤ sum of eigenvalues”).  
Thus, if you merely need an upper bound, you may replace that quotient by
\(\operatorname{tr}S=\nabla\!\cdot f\).

---

### What kind of equation is this?  

It is a *matrix–quadratic–form* inequality—a one-line application of the **min–max principle** for symmetric matrices.  The step from eigenvalue to trace is an elementary **spectral inequality**.

---

### How to approach such bounds systematically  

1. **Identify the quadratic form**  
   Write everything as \(v^{\!\top}A v\) so you can apply spectral facts.

2. **Use min–max**  
   \(\displaystyle\lambda_{\min}(A)\le\frac{v^{\!\top}Av}{|v|^{2}}\le\lambda_{\max}(A)\).

3. **Relate spectrum to trace or norm**  
   * For upper bounds, \(\lambda_{\max}(A)\le\operatorname{tr}A\) if \(A\succeq0\).  
   * More generally, \(\lambda_{\max}(A)\le\|A\|_{\mathrm{op}}\) and  
     \(\|A\|_{\mathrm{op}}\le\|A\|_{\mathsf F}\le\sqrt{d}\,\|A\|_{\mathrm{op}}\).

4. **Insert into the perturbative expansion**  
   Gives explicit, easy-to-control coefficients in front of \(\varepsilon\).

---

### If the upper bound is too crude

- **Tighter local control**: keep \(\lambda_{\max}(S)\) instead of \(\operatorname{tr}S\); diagonalise \(S\) if you know its spectrum.
- **Sign-sensitive estimates**: track \(\lambda_{\min}(S)\) as well when you need lower bounds.
- **Metric-aware bounds**: replace Euclidean \(w\) by Fisher-information metric weighting if a sharper inequality in that geometry matters (this is the “Fisher-metric norm” you saw).

These are standard linear-algebra tools; no special PDE machinery is required until you go beyond the first-order \(\varepsilon\)-expansion.

parts:
Yes — for every fixed blur‐scale \(\varepsilon>0\) there is a (unique) smooth function  

\[
\theta^{\varepsilon}_{t}(x)\;:=\;
-\bigl(\partial_{t}+f(x)\!\cdot\!\nabla\bigr)\,\log \rho^{\varepsilon}_{t}(x),
\qquad 
\rho^{\varepsilon}_{t}=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_{t},
\]

that makes your boxed identity hold along the flowlines \(x_t=\Phi_t(x_0)\):

\[
\rho^{\varepsilon}_{t}(x_t)=
\rho^{\varepsilon}_{0}(x_0)\;
\exp\!\Bigl[-\int_{0}^{t}\theta^{\varepsilon}_{s}\!\bigl(x_s\bigr)\,ds\Bigr].
\]

---

### How to see it

1. **Total (material) derivative along a trajectory.**  
   For any smooth field \(g_t\),

   \[
   \frac{d}{dt}g_t\!\bigl(x_t\bigr)=
   \bigl(\partial_t+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\bigr)g_t\!\bigl(x_t\bigr).
   \]

2. **Apply this to \(\log\rho^{\varepsilon}_t\).**  
   Defining \(\theta^{\varepsilon}_t\) exactly as above ensures

   \[
   \frac{d}{dt}\log\rho^{\varepsilon}_t\!\bigl(x_t\bigr)
   =-\theta^{\varepsilon}_t\!\bigl(x_t\bigr),
   \]

   so integrating from \(0\) to \(t\) and exponentiating gives the desired multiplicative form.

---

### Explicit expression for \(\theta^{\varepsilon}\)

Because \(\rho_t\) itself obeys the Liouville equation \(\partial_t\rho_t=-\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)\),

\[
\partial_t\rho^{\varepsilon}_t
= e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\bigl(-\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)\bigr).
\]

Insert this into the definition of \(\theta^{\varepsilon}\):

\[
\boxed{\;
\theta^{\varepsilon}_{t}(x)=
\frac{\,e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\!\bigl[\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)\bigr](x)\;
-\;f(x)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho^{\varepsilon}_t(x)}
{\rho^{\varepsilon}_t(x)}
\;}
\]

* For each \(\varepsilon>0\) the Gaussian blur \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\) makes \(\rho^{\varepsilon}_t\) strictly positive and \(C^\infty\), so \(\theta^{\varepsilon}_t\) is well-defined and smooth.
* **Unblurred limit.**  Letting \(\varepsilon\downarrow0\) one recovers the classical characteristic result  
  \(\theta^{0}_t(x)=\nabla\!\cdot f(x)\), since \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\to\mathrm{Id}\) and \(\rho^{\varepsilon}_t\to\rho_t\).

---

### Interpretation

* \(\theta^{\varepsilon}\) is the **negative material time derivative of the log-blurred density**.  
* When \(\varepsilon=0\) it reduces to the familiar divergence of the velocity field, because unblurred densities are simply compressed or expanded by the flow.  
* For \(\varepsilon>0\) the Gaussian smoothing couples each point \(x\) to a neighbourhood of size \(\sqrt{\varepsilon}\), so \(\theta^{\varepsilon}\) contains non-local contributions; it is not just the smoothed divergence.

Hence the boxed formula is always valid once you define \(\theta^{\varepsilon}\) as above.

The user wants a proof that when ε = 0, this mimics the standard equation. The goal seems to be to show that θ^ε tends to the divergence of f as ε approaches 0, meaning the equation reduces to the usual Liouville equation in the unblurred case.

I’ll need to compute the limit and demonstrate that it simplifies to ∇·f, which would be a first step in proving the identity. Let’s try approaching it step by step to carefully show the link.

I need to prove that as ε→0, θ_t^ε(x) tends to ∇·f(x). To do this, I’ll show that ρ_t^ε approaches ρ_t and its gradient converges as well. I’ll also evaluate the limit using heat semigroup approximations. I’ll need to handle the smoothing factor carefully to ensure ρ_t doesn’t vanish. The key step is proving that the expression simplifies to ∇·f. I’ll do this by expanding and simplifying the numerator and carefully handling the ε-dependent terms.

parts:
Below is a compact but fully rigorous argument that the “blurred-density” formula

\[
\rho_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x_t)=\rho_{0}^{\varepsilon}(x_0)\;
\exp\!\Bigl[-\int_{0}^{t}\theta_{s}^{\varepsilon}(x_s)\,ds\Bigr],
\qquad
\theta_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x)=-\bigl(\partial_t+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\bigr)\log\rho_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x)
\tag{1}
\]

reduces, as \(\varepsilon\downarrow0\), to the familiar unblurred Liouville‐flow identity

\[
\rho_{t}(x_t)=\rho_{0}(x_0)\;\exp\!\Bigl[-\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f\bigl(x_s\bigr)\,ds\Bigr].
\tag{2}
\]

Throughout, assume \(f\in C^{2}(\mathbb R^{n};\mathbb R^{n})\) and the initial density \(\rho_{0}\in C^{2}_{\mathrm c}(\mathbb R^{n})\) is strictly positive; then every \(\rho_t\) remains \(C^{2}\) and strictly positive on \(\mathbb R^{n}\).

---

### 1.  Identity (1) holds for every fixed \(\varepsilon>0\)

Set \(x_t=\Phi_t(x_0)\), the flow of \(\dot x=f(x)\), and let  
\(g(t)=\log\rho_{t}^{\varepsilon}\!\bigl(x_t\bigr)\).  Differentiating with the **material derivative** gives  

\[
g'(t)=\bigl(\partial_t+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\bigr)\log\rho_{t}^{\varepsilon}\!\bigl(x_t\bigr)
      =-\theta_{t}^{\varepsilon}\!\bigl(x_t\bigr),
\]

so integrating from \(0\) to \(t\) and exponentiating yields (1).

---

### 2.  Explicit form of \(\theta_{t}^{\varepsilon}\)

Because \(\rho_t\) satisfies \(\partial_t\rho_t=-\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)\),

\[
\partial_t\rho_{t}^{\varepsilon}=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\partial_t\rho_t
=-\,e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\!\bigl[\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)\bigr].
\]

Insert this into (1):

\[
\boxed{\;
\theta_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x)=
\frac{\,e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\!\bigl[\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)\bigr](x)\;-\;f(x)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x)}
      {\rho_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x)}\;}.
\tag{3}
\]

---

### 3.  Pointwise limit of \(\theta_{t}^{\varepsilon}\) as \(\varepsilon\downarrow0\)

The heat semigroup \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\) is a **smoothing approximation of the identity**:

\[
\lim_{\varepsilon\downarrow0}e^{\varepsilon\Delta}g=g
\quad\text{in }C^{2}\text{-topology for every }g\in C^{2}.
\]

Applying this to each smooth factor in (3) gives the pointwise limits

\[
\begin{aligned}
e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\bigl[\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)\bigr](x) &\longrightarrow \nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)(x),\\
\nabla\rho_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x)                           &\longrightarrow \nabla\rho_t(x),\\
\rho_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x)                                 &\longrightarrow \rho_t(x)>0.
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence, for every \(x\) with \(\rho_t(x)>0\),

\[
\theta_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x)\xrightarrow[\varepsilon\downarrow0]{}\;
\frac{\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)(x)\;-\;f(x)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t(x)}{\rho_t(x)}
= \nabla\!\cdot f(x).
\tag{4}
\]

(The last equality is the product-rule identity  
\(\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho)=\rho\,\nabla\!\cdot f+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho\).)

---

### 4.  Convergence of the integral in (1)

Fix \(t>0\) and a trajectory \(x_s\).  
Because \(s\mapsto\theta_{s}^{\varepsilon}(x_s)\) converges pointwise to \(\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)\) and is uniformly bounded on \([0,t]\) for small \(\varepsilon\) (smoothness of everything involved), the **dominated-convergence theorem** gives

\[
\int_{0}^{t}\theta_{s}^{\varepsilon}(x_s)\,ds
\;\longrightarrow\;
\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)\,ds.
\tag{5}
\]

---

### 5.  Taking the limit in the multiplicative law

Now take \(\varepsilon\downarrow0\) in (1):

\[
\rho_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x_t)\;\longrightarrow\;\rho_t(x_t),\qquad
\rho_{0}^{\varepsilon}(x_0)\;\longrightarrow\;\rho_0(x_0),
\]

and combine these with (5).  The result is exactly (2).  Thus **the blurred identity collapses to the standard Liouville characteristic formula when the blur radius shrinks to zero**, proving the desired statement.

---

### Remarks

* The proof is purely analytic; no probabilistic or measure-theoretic subtleties enter because the heat semigroup acts nicely on \(C^{2}\) functions.
* If \(\rho_t\) vanishes at some spatial points, one restricts attention to regions where \(\rho_t>0\); the argument above then applies on each connected component.
* Higher-order expansions of (3) show that  
  \(\theta_{t}^{\varepsilon}(x)=\nabla\!\cdot f(x)+O(\varepsilon)\) uniformly on compact sets, quantifying how well the blurred dynamics approximates the unblurred one for small \(\varepsilon\).

To simplify \(\theta^{\varepsilon}\), I'll use commutators. After applying the product rule, I see that the expression can be reduced further by recognizing that the commutators of the heat semigroup with the advection operator result in a more compact form. The final simplified form becomes:

parts:
Below is the neatest way to package \(\theta_t^{\varepsilon}\) in **one line** by isolating a single commutator.

---

### 1 Start from the definition  
\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}(x)\;
=\;
\frac{\,e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\!\bigl[-\nabla\!\cdot (f\rho_t)\bigr](x)\;-\;f(x)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x)}
       {\rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x)},
\qquad
\rho_t^{\varepsilon}=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t .
\]

### 2 Use the product rule once  
\[
\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_t)=(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho_t+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t .
\]

Insert this and collect the two \(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\) terms:

\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
=\frac{(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho_t^{\varepsilon}
      \;+\;\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta}f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t
        -f\!\cdot\!\nabla e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t\bigr]}
     {\rho_t^{\varepsilon}}\;.
\]

The bracketed difference **is exactly a commutator**:

\[
\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla\bigr]\rho_t
:=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t)
  -f\!\cdot\!\nabla(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t).
\]

### 3 Result  
\[
\boxed{\;
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}(x)
=\nabla\!\cdot f(x)
+\frac{\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla\bigr]\rho_t}{\rho_t^{\varepsilon}}\!(x)
\;}
\tag{★}
\]

So **all \(\varepsilon\)-dependence has been swept into one commutator** of the heat-semigroup \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\) with the advection operator \(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\).  
Nothing else remains to simplify.

---

## 4 Small-blur expansion (optional)

Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff gives, for any operator \(A\),

\[
\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},A\bigr]
=\varepsilon\!\int_{0}^{1}e^{(1-s)\varepsilon\Delta}\,[\Delta,A]\,e^{s\varepsilon\Delta}\,ds,
\]

so (★) turns into

\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
=\nabla\!\cdot f
+\varepsilon\,\rho_t^{\varepsilon\,\!-1}
      \!\int_{0}^{1}\!e^{(1-s)\varepsilon\Delta}
      [\,\Delta,\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla\,]\,
      e^{s\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t\,ds
+O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\]

Since  
\[
[\Delta,\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla]g
=(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla g
\;+\;2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}:\nabla\nabla g,
\]
the first-order correction simplifies to

\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
=\nabla\!\cdot f
\;+\;\varepsilon\;
\frac{(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t
      +2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}:\nabla\nabla\rho_t}{\rho_t}
\;+\;O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\]

agreeing with the classical value \(\nabla\!\cdot f\) as \(\varepsilon\!\downarrow\!0\).

---

### Take-aways
* **Exact form (★)**: \(\displaystyle\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
      =\nabla\!\cdot f+\rho_t^{\varepsilon\,\!-1}\,[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},f\!\cdot\!\nabla]\rho_t.\)
* The commutator vanishes when \(f\) is spatially constant, so \(\theta^{\varepsilon}\) then reduces to the ordinary divergence regardless of blur.
* For smooth \(f\), the commutator is \(O(\varepsilon)\), giving a clean perturbative expansion whenever the blur radius \(\sqrt{\varepsilon}\) is small.

parts:
Because the heat kernel is strictly positive, **any non-zero amount of blur already forces the blurred density to be strictly positive everywhere.**  
More precisely:

---

### Heat–kernel positivity

For each \(\varepsilon>0\)

\[
\rho^{\varepsilon}_t(x)
=\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}
\underbrace{\frac{1}{(4\pi\varepsilon)^{n/2}}
           e^{-\lvert x-y\rvert^{2}/4\varepsilon}}_{K_\varepsilon(x-y)>0}
\,
\rho_t(y)\,dy .
\]

If \(\rho_t\) is non-negative and not identically zero (true whenever \(\rho_0\ge0\) and \(\int\rho_0=1\)), then for every \(x\)

\[
\rho^{\varepsilon}_t(x)\;=\;\int K_\varepsilon(x-y)\rho_t(y)\,dy>0 ,
\]
because the integrand is positive on a set of positive measure.

---

### What you must require for all \(t\)

1. **Strictly positive blur radius**  
   \[
   \boxed{\;\varepsilon(t)>0\quad\text{for every }t\ge0\;}
   \]
   (It may go to \(0\) as \(t\to\infty\); at any finite time the value just has to remain non-zero.)

2. **A non-trivial density**  
   \(\rho_t\not\equiv0\), automatically satisfied if \(\rho_0\) is a genuine probability density and the Liouville flow conserves mass.

Nothing else is needed.  In particular you do **not** have to lower-bound \(\varepsilon(t)\) away from zero uniformly in \(t\) unless you also want a uniform positive lower bound on \(\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}\).  For mere pointwise positivity, the condition \(\varepsilon(t)>0\) is already sufficient.

parts:
### Heuristic picture Along the trajectory \(x_t=\Phi_t(x_0)\) the **raw** density satisfies \[ \rho_t(x_t)=\rho_0(x_0)\, \exp\!\Bigl[-\textstyle\int_0^{t}\!\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)\,ds\Bigr]. \tag{1} \] Now blur at scale \(\sqrt{\varepsilon(t)}\): \[ \rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t) =\bigl(G_{\varepsilon(t)}*\rho_t\bigr)(x_t) \;=\;\int_{\mathbb R^{n}} \frac{e^{-|y|^{2}/4\varepsilon(t)}}{(4\pi\varepsilon(t))^{n/2}} \,\rho_t(x_t-y)\,dy . \tag{2} \] For small \(\varepsilon\) the kernel is concentrated in a ball of radius \(r=\sqrt{\varepsilon}\); the mass it captures is roughly \(\rho_t(x_t)\,r^{n}\), and the averaging volume is \(r^{n}\). Hence, to leading order, \[ \rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)\;\sim\;\rho_t(x_t) \quad\text{as }\varepsilon(t)\downarrow0. \tag{3} \] So the *only* way the blurred density can go to \(0\) is if the “raw” factor (1) decays to \(0\) **faster** than we let the blur radius collapse. --- ### A quantitative lower bound Combine (1)–(3) more carefully (keep the volume factor explicitly): \[ \rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)\;\gtrsim\; \rho_0(x_0)\, \exp\!\Bigl[-\!\!\int_0^{t}\!\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)\,ds\Bigr]\; \varepsilon(t)^{-n/2}. \tag{4} \] (The constant implicit in \(\gtrsim\) depends only on the kernel shape.) Therefore \[ \boxed{\; \liminf_{t\to\infty} \bigl[\, \varepsilon(t)^{\,n/2}\; e^{-\int_0^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)\,ds} \bigr] >0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad \lim_{t\to\infty}\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)>0 . \;} \tag{5} \] Conversely, if the bracketed factor in (5) tends to \(0\), the right‐hand side of (4) forces \(\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)\to0\). --- ### What does condition (5) mean? Write \[ J(t):=\exp\!\Bigl(\int_0^{t}\!\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)\,ds\Bigr) \quad\bigl(\text{Jacobian determinant of the flow}\bigr), \] so \(\rho_t(x_t)=\rho_0(x_0)/J(t)\). Then (5) is \[ \boxed{\; \varepsilon(t)\;\gtrsim\;J(t)^{-2/n}\quad(t\ \text{large}).\;} \tag{6} \] --- ### Two important cases | dynamical regime | behaviour of \(J(t)\) | requirement on \(\varepsilon(t)\) | |------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------------------| | **dissipative / volume-contracting**
(\(\displaystyle\limsup_{t\to\infty}\tfrac1t\!\int_0^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f<0\)) | \(J(t)\) is bounded | *Any* positive \(\varepsilon(t)\downarrow0\) works. | | **volume-expanding**
(\(\displaystyle\liminf_{t\to\infty}\tfrac1t\!\int_0^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f=\gamma>0\)) | \(J(t)\sim e^{\gamma t}\) | You must keep the blur radius from collapsing faster than \(e^{-\gamma t/n}\):
\(\displaystyle\varepsilon(t)\;\ge\;C\,e^{-2\gamma t/n}\) for some \(C>0\). The safest choice is to **freeze** the blur at a small constant \(\varepsilon_{\min}>0\). | --- ### Rule of thumb (differential form) \[ \boxed{\; \frac{d}{dt}\log\varepsilon(t) \;\ge\; -\frac{2}{n}\,\nabla\!\cdot f\bigl(x_t\bigr) \qquad\text{for large }t. \;} \tag{7} \] It says: *shrink the blur length scale \(\sqrt{\varepsilon}\) no faster than the local exponential contraction of volume*. --- ### Summary To ensure \[ \lim_{t\to\infty}\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)\;>\;0, \] choose the blur schedule so that the inequality (6) (or its equivalent forms (5)/(7)) holds. In practice: * If the flow is **volume-contracting on average**, you may let \(\varepsilon(t)\) go to zero arbitrarily slowly or quickly—any positive schedule works. * If the flow has **positive average divergence**, you must prevent the variance from shrinking too fast; concretely, keep \(\varepsilon(t)\) bounded below by an exponential of rate \(-2\gamma/n\), or simply stop shrinking it once it reaches a small fixed floor.

parts:
Below is a **small-\(\varepsilon\) bookkeeping exercise** that turns the
commutator formula for  
\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}(x)
=\nabla\!\cdot f(x)+\frac{[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla]\rho_t}
             {\rho_t^{\varepsilon}}(x)
\tag{1}
\]
into an explicit *balance condition* on a time–dependent blur
\(\varepsilon(t)\) that guarantees  
\[
\boxed{\;\displaystyle
0<\lim_{t\to\infty}\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)<\infty\;} .
\]

---

## 1 First‐order expansion of \(\theta_t^{\varepsilon}\)

Using the heat-kernel BCH identity
\( [\,e^{\varepsilon\Delta},A\,]=\varepsilon\,[\Delta,A]+O(\varepsilon^{2}) \)
and the product rule
\([\Delta,f\!\cdot\!\nabla]\rho_t
      =(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t
       +2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\rho_t,\)
one gets, **uniformly on compact sets**,

\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}(x)
   =\nabla\!\cdot f(x)
   \;+\;\varepsilon\,R_t(x)\;+\;O(\varepsilon^{2}),\qquad
R_t(x):=\frac{(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t
                   +2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\rho_t}
                  {\rho_t}(x).
\tag{2}
\]

\(R_t\) is \(C^{1}\) in space and—because \(\rho_t\) solves a smooth PDE—
locally bounded in time.

> **Key point:**  
> At leading order, adding blur replaces the raw divergence
> \(\nabla\!\cdot f\) by a *corrected* divergence
> \(\nabla\!\cdot f+\varepsilon R_t\).

---

## 2 The trajectory equation

Along any flowline \(x_t=\Phi_t(x_0)\),

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\log\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)
   =-\theta_t^{\varepsilon(t)}\bigl(x_t\bigr)
   =-\bigl[\nabla\!\cdot f(x_t)
           +\varepsilon(t)\,R_t(x_t)
           +O\!\bigl(\varepsilon(t)^2\bigr)\bigr].
\tag{3}
\]

Integrate from \(0\) to \(t\):

\[
\log\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)
  =\log\rho_0^{\varepsilon(0)}(x_0)
   -\int_{0}^{t}\!\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)\,ds
   -\int_{0}^{t}\!\varepsilon(s)\,R_s(x_s)\,ds
   +O\!\Bigl(\int_{0}^{t}\!\varepsilon(s)^2\,ds\Bigr).
\tag{4}
\]

Call the three integrals on the right
\(I_0(t),I_1(t),I_2(t)\), in that order.

---

## 3 What must stay bounded?

For  
\(\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)\to\rho_\infty>0\)
it is **necessary and sufficient** that  
\[
\boxed{\;
I(t):=I_0(t)+I_1(t)+I_2(t)
\quad\text{remains bounded as }t\to\infty.\;}
\tag{5}
\]

Because \(\varepsilon(t)\ll1\), \(I_2(t)\) is always of *lower* order
(\(\int\varepsilon^2\)) and cannot save us from a divergence of
\(I_0+I_1\).  Thus the crux is to **cancel the unblurred divergence
\(I_0(t)\)** with the linear-in-\(\varepsilon\) term \(I_1(t)\).

---

## 4 A clean algebraic criterion

Divide by \(t\) and take a limit along the trajectory (Cesàro average):

\[
\gamma\;:=\;\limsup_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\,I_0(t)
         \;=\;\limsup_{t\to\infty}
                \frac1t\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)\,ds,
\tag{6}
\]

\[
\bar R\;:=\;\liminf_{t\to\infty}
          \frac1t\int_{0}^{t}R_s(x_s)\,ds
          \quad(\text{exists because }R_s\text{ is bounded}).
\tag{7}
\]

Keeping only the *first* two terms of (4):

\[
I_0(t)+I_1(t)\sim
t\,\Bigl[\gamma+\overline{\varepsilon R}\Bigr],
\qquad
\overline{\varepsilon R}:=\;\limsup_{t\to\infty}
  \frac1t\int_{0}^{t}\varepsilon(s)R_s(x_s)\,ds.
\tag{8}
\]

> **Boundedness condition:**  
> \[
> \boxed{\;
> \gamma+\overline{\varepsilon R}=0.
> \;}
> \tag{9}
> \]

If (9) holds, \(I(t)\) stays \(O(1)\); if it fails, \(I(t)\) drifts
linearly to \(+\infty\) (density vanishes) or \(-\infty\) (blows up).

---

## 5 Designing \(\varepsilon(t)\)

Because \(\varepsilon(t)\) appears only *multiplicatively* in (8),
the simplest workable schedule is **constant blur**:

\[
\varepsilon(t)\equiv\varepsilon_{\star},
\qquad
\varepsilon_{\star} := -\frac{\gamma}{\bar R}.
\tag{10}
\]

This succeeds provided

* \(0<\varepsilon_{\star}\ll1\) (we are in the “small-\(\varepsilon\)’’
  regime); i.e.  
  **\(\gamma\) and \(\bar R\) must have opposite signs**, and  
  \(|\gamma/\bar R|\) must be small.

When \(\gamma=0\) (volume-preserving on average) condition (9) is
automatic; *any* slowly decaying \(\varepsilon(t)\) works.

---

### 5.1 If constant blur is impossible  

Some systems give \(\bar R\) that changes sign or is very small, so
\(\varepsilon_{\star}\) would be negative or too large.  
In that case choose a **piecewise schedule** satisfying

\[
\boxed{\;
\int_{0}^{\infty}\!\bigl[\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)
      +\varepsilon(s)R_s(x_s)\bigr]\,ds
      \text{ converges.}
\;}
\tag{11}
\]

A practical recipe:

1. **Estimate running averages**  
   \(\Gamma(t)=\frac1t\int_0^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)ds\) and  
   \(R_{\mathrm{avg}}(t)=\frac1t\int_0^{t}R_s(x_s)ds\).
2. Keep \(\varepsilon(t)\) *small but positive* and adjust it slowly so
   that  
   \(\Gamma(t)+\varepsilon(t)R_{\mathrm{avg}}(t)\) is nudged toward \(0\).

Because both integrands are bounded, even a **logarithmically slow**
feedback (e.g. \(\dot\varepsilon\sim-1/t\)) suffices.

---

## 6 What this buys you

* **If the flow is volume-expanding on average**
  (\(\gamma>0\)) you *must* keep the blur radius from collapsing too
  fast; (10) tells you how large it has to be.
* **If the flow is contracting on average**
  (\(\gamma<0\)) you *must not* let the blur grow too large, or the
  density will blow up; again (10) quantifies “how small is small”.
* **If the flow is incompressible on average**
  (\(\gamma=0\)), blur is irrelevant to the long-time limit as long as
  \(\varepsilon(t)\to0\) no faster than, say, \(1/t\).

---

## 7 Take-away formula

\[
\boxed{\;
\text{Choose }\varepsilon(t)\text{ so that }
\lim_{t\to\infty}
\int_{0}^{t}\!
\bigl[\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)
      +\varepsilon(s)\,R_s(x_s)\bigr]\,ds
\text{ converges.}
\;}
\tag{12}
\]

With  
\(R_s(x)=\dfrac{(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_s
               +2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\rho_s}
              {\rho_s}(x)\).

Equation (12) is **both necessary and sufficient** (to
\(O(\varepsilon)\)) for the blurred density to settle to a positive
finite limit along the chosen trajectory.

---

### 8 Why this is sharper than the earlier bound

* The previous heuristic matched blur only to the *volume factor*
  \(e^{-\int\nabla\!\cdot f}\).  
  It ignored the \(R\)-term, which is \(O(\varepsilon)\) but
  \emph{multiplied by time}.  Over long horizons that linear‐in-time
  piece is what actually cancels the divergence.
* Formula (12) makes that cancellation explicit and shows that—
  provided \(R_s\) does not vanish identically—one can stabilise
  \(\rho_t^{\varepsilon}\) with a **fixed**, arbitrarily small blur
  (or, if signs do not cooperate, shows when that is impossible).

---

## 9 Caveats

1. All estimates are first-order in \(\varepsilon\).
   If you choose \(\varepsilon_{\star}\) of size, say, \(10^{-2}\),
   the neglected \(O(\varepsilon^{2})\) integral in (4) stays
   \(O(10^{-2})\) over any time horizon of physical interest.
2. If \(R_s\) occasionally changes sign, use a *bounded* but
   slowly varying \(\varepsilon(t)\); (12) still applies.
3. If the trajectory wanders into regions where
   \(\rho_s\) becomes extremely small, \(R_s\) may blow up;
   then **no** small blur schedule can help—one must revisit the
   modelling assumptions.

With those understood, Eq. (12) is the tightest condition you can
extract directly from the commutator expansion (2).

The user seems to propose that for large t, the term \(\Delta f \cdot \nabla \log \rho\) can be neglected. I think they're asking for a justification. To explain, we could consider how, in dissipative systems, density becomes concentrated on attractors, with the gradient potentially decaying faster than the second derivative (Hessian). parts:
Yes — under the usual **contracting-flow** assumptions the
\((\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t\) piece becomes negligible compared
with the “double-dot’’ term
\((\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_t\) as \(t\to\infty\).
Here is the scaling argument you were anticipating and the conditions
under which it is rigorous.

---

### 1 Recall the \(O(\varepsilon)\) correction

For small blur one has  
\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
 \;=\;\nabla\!\cdot f
   +\varepsilon\Bigl[(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t
                     +2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_t\Bigr]
   +O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\]
Call the two \(O(\varepsilon)\) pieces
\[
A_t:=(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t,
\qquad
B_t:=2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_t .
\]

---

### 2 How the two terms scale along a trajectory

Let \(x_t=\Phi_t(x_0)\) and denote by
\(\mathrm D\Phi_{-t}(x_t)\in\mathbb R^{n\times n}\) the inverse (backward-time)
Jacobian of the flow.  Write \(\sigma_{\max}(t)\) and
\(\sigma_{\min}(t)\) for its largest and smallest singular values.
For a typical dissipative system

\[
\sigma_{\max}(t)\sim e^{\lambda_{\max}t},
\qquad
\sigma_{\min}(t)\sim e^{-\lambda_{\min}t},
\qquad
\lambda_{\max},\lambda_{\min}>0.
\tag{1}
\]

---

#### 2.1 Gradient of the density

The push-forward formula gives  

\[
\nabla\rho_t(x_t)=
\mathrm D\Phi_{-t}(x_t)^{\!\top}\,
                \nabla\rho_0(x_0)\,
                e^{-\!\int_0^t\nabla\!\cdot f(x_s)ds}.
\]

Hence
\[
\|\nabla\rho_t\|\;\lesssim\;
\sigma_{\max}(t)\,\rho_t\Big/\ell_0,
\tag{2}
\]
where \(\ell_0\) is the characteristic length of \(\rho_0\).

---

#### 2.2 Hessian of the density

Differentiating once more brings in a product of **two** Jacobian factors,
so generically  

\[
\|\nabla\nabla\rho_t\|
\;\lesssim\;\sigma_{\max}(t)^2\,\rho_t\Big/\ell_0^{2}.
\tag{3}
\]

(Even if the flow is only \(C^{2}\), \(\sigma_{\max}(t)^2\) is the right
order of magnitude; see standard proofs of regularity transfer under
push-forward.)

---

### 3 Relative size of \(A_t\) and \(B_t\)

Because \(f\) is fixed and smooth, \(\Delta f\) and \(\nabla f\) are
bounded.  Combine (2)–(3) to get

\[
\frac{|A_t|}{|B_t|}
\;\lesssim\;
\frac{\|\nabla\rho_t\|}{\|\nabla\nabla\rho_t\|}
\;\sim\;
\frac{1}{\sigma_{\max}(t)}
\;\sim\;
e^{-\lambda_{\max}t}\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}0.
\tag{4}
\]

So along any trajectory with **positive forward Lyapunov exponent
\(\lambda_{\max}>0\)** the
\((\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t\) term is indeed suppressed by the
rapid contraction of length-scales, while the double-dot term is not.

---

### 4 When the simplification fails

1. **Incompressible or neutrally stable flows**  
   If \(\sigma_{\max}(t)\) stays \(O(1)\) (e.g. Hamiltonian or shear
   flows), the ratio (4) does not vanish; both \(A_t\) and \(B_t\) are
   of the same order and you cannot drop \(A_t\).

2. **Regions where \(\rho_t\) is already smooth**  
   If the trajectory lives permanently in a set where \(\rho_t\)
   approaches a positive \(C^{2}\) limit, \(\|\nabla\rho_t\|\) and
   \(\|\nabla\nabla\rho_t\|\) remain bounded; again no separation.

3. **Finite-time arguments**  
   For practical time horizons the suppression factor is
   \(e^{-\lambda_{\max}t}\).  If \(t\lambda_{\max}=10\) the error is on
   the order of \(10^{-4}\); if \(t\lambda_{\max}=2\) it is only about
   \(15\%\).  Check against your application’s tolerance.

---

### 5 Resulting \(O(\varepsilon)\) approximation

Under the contracting-flow hypothesis:

\[
\boxed{\;
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}(x_t)
      =\nabla\!\cdot f(x_t)
       \;+\;\varepsilon\,
         2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_t(x_t)
       \;+\;O\!\bigl(\varepsilon e^{-\lambda_{\max}t}\bigr)
       \;+\;O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\;}
\]

The discarded \(A_t\) term is already multiplied by \(\varepsilon\); the
extra exponential factor makes it insignificant for large \(t\).

---

### 6 Implication for your blur schedule

With this sharper form you need only balance the *single* quantity  
\(B_t=2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_t\) against the
unblurred divergence when choosing \(\varepsilon(t)\).  In the notation
of the previous reply, the replacement
\(R_t\mapsto R_t^{\text{red}}:=2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}
                               \!:\nabla\nabla\rho_t/\rho_t\)
makes all the criteria identical, but with a slightly larger allowable
range of \(\varepsilon_{\star}\) because \(R_t^{\text{red}}\) is the
dominant piece.

---

#### Bottom line
*For trajectories with positive Lyapunov expansion rate the
\(\Delta f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t\) term decays like
\(e^{-\lambda_{\max}t}\) and can be dropped from the
\(O(\varepsilon)\) correction.  The asymptotics of \(\theta\) are then
controlled solely by the “double-dot’’ contraction
\(2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_t\).*

parts:
A quick trick is to **renormalise the blurred density by the un-blurred one**.  
Set

\[
u_t^{\varepsilon}(x)\;:=\;\frac{\rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x)}{\rho_t(x)}
      \;=\;\exp\!\Bigl[\log\rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x)-\log\rho_t(x)\Bigr].
\]

---

### What happens along a trajectory \(x_t=\Phi_t(x_0)\)

Because

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\log\rho_t(x_t)
       =-(\partial_t+f\!\cdot\!\nabla)\log\rho_t(x_t)
       =\nabla\!\cdot f(x_t),
\]

you get

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\log u_t^{\varepsilon}(x_t)
      =-\Bigl[\theta_t^{\varepsilon}(x_t)-\nabla\!\cdot f(x_t)\Bigr],
\]

so the **divergence term cancels identically**.  Equivalently,

\[
u_t^{\varepsilon}(x_t)
      =u_0^{\varepsilon}(x_0)\;
       \exp\!\Bigl[-\!\int_{0}^{t}
                   \bigl(\theta_s^{\varepsilon}-\nabla\!\cdot f\bigr)(x_s)\,ds
              \Bigr].
\tag{★}
\]

---

### In small-\(\varepsilon\) form

With the commutator expansion

\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}
  =\nabla\!\cdot f
   +\varepsilon\,2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_t
   +O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\]

the bracket in (★) is just the **\(O(\varepsilon)\) correction**

\[
\theta_t^{\varepsilon}-\nabla\!\cdot f
   =\varepsilon\,2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_t
    +O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\]

Hence

\[
\log u_t^{\varepsilon}(x_t)
   =\log u_0^{\varepsilon}(x_0)
    -\int_{0}^{t}\varepsilon(s)\,
          2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_s(x_s)\,ds
    +O\!\Bigl(\int_{0}^{t}\varepsilon(s)^{2}ds\Bigr).
\]

---

### Why this helps

* All leading-order volume-change effects are gone; what remains is of
  size \(\varepsilon\).
* To keep \(\rho_t^{\varepsilon}(x_t)\) bounded away from zero you now
  only have to control
  \(\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\infty}\varepsilon(s)
    \bigl|(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_s\bigr|ds\).
  Any blur schedule with  
  \(\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\infty}\varepsilon(s)ds<\infty\) does the
  job if that double-dot factor stays bounded along the trajectory.

---

### Summary

1. **Divide the blurred density by the raw density:**  
   \(u_t^{\varepsilon}=\rho_t^{\varepsilon}/\rho_t\).
2. The divergence term \(\nabla\!\cdot f\) cancels automatically.
3. The long-time behaviour of \(u_t^{\varepsilon}\) is governed only by
   the commutator piece \(2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}:\nabla\nabla\log\rho_t\),
   which is \(O(\varepsilon)\).

That single step — subtracting (or, multiplicatively, dividing by)
\(\log\rho_t\) — removes the \(\nabla\!\cdot f\) obstacle you were
concerned about.
Assume nabla f is exactly zero. If I want the denominator to be >0, what do I need?

thoughts.content: The user is working with an expression involving the gradient of f (nabla f). If nabla f is zero, it means the function f is constant, so its divergence is also zero. This would mean that the terms involving the divergence of f will not contribute anything to θ_t^ε. In this case, other derivatives of f also vanish, and therefore θ_t^ε reduces to zero. The commutator acting on ρ_t wouldn't add any new terms either since the function f is constant. Interesting simplification!

If \( f \) is constant, the commutator \( [\Delta, f \cdot \nabla] \) is zero, which makes \( \theta = \text{div} \, f = 0 \). This means the material derivative of \( \log \rho_t^\epsilon \) is zero, so it's constant along flow. To ensure the denominator stays positive (\( \rho_t^\epsilon > 0 \)), we need \( \rho_t^\epsilon(x) \) to stay positive for all \( t \). Essentially, we need to make sure the Gaussian-blurred distribution remains positive in the large \( t \) limit, which depends on the shift in the density and variance of \( \epsilon(t) \).

For the denominator to stay positive, we need the initial density \( \rho_0(x_0) \) to be positive and for the convolution with the Gaussian kernel not to vanish too quickly. If \( \nabla f = 0 \), then the flow is just translation, and the density along the trajectory stays constant. The key requirement is that as \( \epsilon(t) \to 0 \), the blurred density stays positive. This happens if the initial density doesn't vanish too sharply near \( x_0 \). So, \( \rho_0(x_0) > 0 \) ensures that the denominator remains positive in the limit.

parts:
Because \(\nabla f\equiv0\) the velocity field \(f\) is a **constant translation**. All spatial derivatives of \(f\) vanish, so * \(\nabla\!\cdot f = 0\), * \([\Delta,\;f\!\cdot\!\nabla]=0\), * hence \(\theta^{\varepsilon}_t\equiv0\). The characteristic formula therefore collapses to a simple **shift–blur identity** \[ \rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)= \bigl(G_{\varepsilon(t)}*\rho_0\bigr)(x_0), \qquad x_t=x_0+f\,t, \tag{1} \] where \(G_{\varepsilon}\) is the Gaussian kernel with variance \(2\varepsilon\). Thus the denominator in every earlier formula is just the \(\varepsilon(t)\)-blur of the *fixed* initial density evaluated at the *fixed* point \(x_0\): \[ D(t):=\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)= \int_{\mathbb R^{n}} \frac{e^{-|y|^{2}/4\varepsilon(t)}}{(4\pi\varepsilon(t))^{n/2}} \,\rho_0(x_0-y)\,dy . \tag{2} \] --- ### Necessary & sufficient condition for \(D(t)>0\) as \(t\to\infty\) Choose **any blur schedule** \(t\mapsto\varepsilon(t)>0\). Then \[ \boxed{\; \liminf_{t\to\infty}D(t)>0 \;\Longleftrightarrow\; \liminf_{t\to\infty}\bigl(G_{\varepsilon(t)}*\rho_0\bigr)(x_0)>0. \;} \tag{3} \] Because \(\rho_0\ge0\) and the Gaussian is strictly positive, (3) boils down to the behaviour of \(\rho_0\) in a shrinking neighbourhood of \(x_0\). --- ### Two practical ways to satisfy (3) | how to guarantee \(D(t)>0\) | what it means in practice | |-----------------------------|---------------------------| | **(A)**  Pick an initial point where the raw density is positive
\(\displaystyle \rho_0(x_0)>0.\) | Then \(G_{\varepsilon}\!*\,\rho_0\to\rho_0(x_0)\) as \(\varepsilon\!\downarrow0\); any schedule with \(\varepsilon(t)\to0\) (or even a constant blur) works. | | **(B)**  Keep the blur radius from collapsing completely
\(\displaystyle \inf_{t\ge0}\varepsilon(t)\;>\;0.\) | Even if \(\rho_0(x_0)=0\), the fixed-width Gaussian averages over a ball where \(\rho_0\) has positive mass, so the convolution stays bounded below. | *(B) is often used in numerics: one freezes the blur once it reaches a small “grid scale’’.* --- ### When it is impossible If * \(\rho_0(x_0)=0\) **and** * \(\varepsilon(t)\to0\) as \(t\to\infty\), then \(D(t)\to0\) — no choice of faster/slower schedule can rescue the limit, because the Gaussian collapses onto a point where the initial density vanishes. --- ### Summary With \(\nabla f=0\) the flow neither compresses nor stretches volume, so the only thing that can drive the blurred density to zero is the **local behaviour of the initial density around the starting point**. To keep the denominator positive for all large \(t\), *either* start in a spot where \(\rho_0\) itself is positive, *or* stop shrinking the blur once it reaches a fixed positive width. No other conditions are needed.

thoughts.content: The user is asking about a case where the divergence of a function \( \mathbf{f} \) is zero. They're wondering what needs to be true for the denominator to be positive. The conversation seems to be related to the blurred density \( \rho_t^\varepsilon \) along trajectories and the condition for \( \rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t) \) to converge to a positive limit. If the divergence of \( \mathbf{f} \) is zero (as in incompressible flow), then the density remains preserved along trajectories, implying no compression or expansion. This leads to conservation of density in the Liouville equation.

The user is asking about conditions for the denominator in the expression for theta to be greater than zero. In the context of the Liouville equation, when the divergence of \( \mathbf{f} \) is zero, the density \( \rho \) is constant along the trajectory, meaning the blurred density should remain positive if it started that way. The user likely wants to ensure that either \( \rho_t^\varepsilon(x) > 0 \) or \( \rho_t(x) > 0 \) to keep the denominator positive. This ties into keeping \( \rho_t \) positive for consistency.

To ensure the denominator stays positive, we need the initial density \( \rho_0 \) to be strictly positive and choose a small but non-zero value for \( \varepsilon(t) \). The convolution and smoothing process should preserve the positivity of density. Since the flow is incompressible and density remains constant along trajectories, the denominator will stay positive if \( \rho_0(x_0) > 0 \). The epsilon schedule must decay slowly enough to ensure the integral of \( \varepsilon(s) R_s \) remains finite, which guarantees the denominator doesn't vanish.

parts:
Because the flow is **incompressible**  
\[
\nabla\!\cdot f\equiv0 ,
\]
the Liouville equation tells us that the *raw* density is transported
without stretching or squeezing:

\[
\rho_t(x_t)=\rho_0(x_0)\quad\text{for every trajectory }x_t=\Phi_t(x_0).
\tag{1}
\]

---

## 1 What appears in the denominator

In all the formulas we have been using the denominator that worries you
is

\[
\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)
   =\bigl(G_{\varepsilon(t)} * \rho_t\bigr)(x_t)
   =\underbrace{(G_{\varepsilon(t)} * \rho_0)(x_0)}_{\displaystyle\text{depends only on }x_0}.
\tag{2}
\]

Here \(G_\varepsilon\) is the Gaussian kernel of variance \(2\varepsilon\).

Because \(G_\varepsilon\) is **strictly positive** everywhere,
\(\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)\) can vanish *only* if the initial
density is identically zero in the ball that the kernel averages over.  
That leads to two complementary ways of keeping the denominator positive.

---

## 2 Option A – Strictly positive initial data

If the initial density never hits zero,

\[
\boxed{\;\rho_0(x)\ge m>0\quad\text{for all }x\in\mathbb R^{n}\;},
\tag{3}
\]

then (2) is bounded away from zero for **any** blur schedule
\(\varepsilon(t)>0\) (even if it slowly shrinks to \(0\)).
Indeed,

\[
\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)\;\ge\;m\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\!G_{\varepsilon(t)}(y)\,dy
                              \;=\;m>0 .
\]

---

## 3 Option B – Allow zeros in \(\rho_0\)

If \(\rho_0\) has zeroes, positivity is still guaranteed provided the
blur radius never collapses faster than your trajectory can leave the
nearest region of positive mass.  The precise requirement is

\[
\boxed{\;
\varepsilon(t)\;\ge\;\varepsilon_{\min}>0
\quad\text{whenever }x_0\text{ lies at distance }>\!0
\text{ from the zero set of }\rho_0 .
\;}
\tag{4}
\]

With (4) the convolution in (2) always averages in **some** positive
density, hence \(\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)>0\).

A convenient practical test is

\[
\int_0^\infty\varepsilon(t)\,dt<\infty
\;\Longrightarrow\;
\text{the integral correction }{\displaystyle
\int_0^\infty\varepsilon(t)B_t\,dt}
\text{ converges},
\]

so \(\log\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)\) stays bounded and the denominator
never hits zero.  Any schedule that decays faster than \(1/t^{1+\delta}\)
(\(\delta>0\)) satisfies this automatically.

---

## 4 Putting it in words

* **If you start with a strictly positive density everywhere, you are
  safe no matter how you let the blur radius shrink.**

* **If the initial density has holes, keep the blur radius from
  collapsing completely** (or at least do so slowly enough that the
  Gaussian still “sees’’ some positive mass).  A fixed small floor
  \(\varepsilon_{\min}\) or any integrable‐in‐time schedule works.

Either strategy guarantees that the denominator
\(\rho_t^{\varepsilon(t)}(x_t)\) stays strictly \(>\!0\) for all
\(t\) and along every trajectory.
And if \nabla \cdot f is less than 0 on average then the denominator will always be positive right?
